verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: This introductory formula is identical to Hebrew; the division in English and Hebrew Bibles of the verses and chapters may differ.

verses.text: If anyone sins and is unfaithful to the Lord by deceiving his neighbor about something entrusted to him, or something left in his care, or about something stolen, or if he has extorted something from his neighbor,
verses.comment: The translation preserves each case specified in Hebrew and clarifies in modern language.

verses.text: or if he finds lost property and lies about it, or he swears falsely about any such sin that a man commits,
verses.comment: The structure “or if…” mirrors the Hebrew connective pattern.

verses.text: if he has sinned and is guilty, he must return what he has stolen, or what he extorted, or what was entrusted to him, or the lost property he found,
verses.comment: Faithful to the direct list of requirements in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: or anything about which he swore falsely. He must make full restitution, adding a fifth of its value to it, and give it to the owner on the day he offers his guilt offering.
verses.comment: Maintains exactness in restitution amount (a fifth = 20%).

verses.text: Then he shall bring to the priest, as his guilt offering to the Lord, a ram without defect from the flock, or its equivalent, according to your assessment, for a guilt offering.
verses.comment: ‘Your assessment’ is addressed to Moses or the priest; ‘equivalent’ clarifies the value principle.

verses.text: The priest shall make atonement for him before the Lord, and he will be forgiven for any of the things he did that made him guilty.
verses.comment: Clear, modern rendering of the priestly atonement function and forgiveness.

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Phrase repeated as in the original Hebrew to start a new section.

verses.text: Command Aaron and his sons, saying, This is the law of the burnt offering: The burnt offering shall remain on the altar hearth all night until the morning, and the fire on the altar shall be kept burning on it.
verses.comment: ‘Hearth’ translates Hebrew ‘mokdah’ accurately. ‘Law’ = ‘torah’ (instruction).

verses.text: The priest shall put on his linen garment and linen undergarments next to his body, and he shall remove the ashes from the burnt offering that the fire has consumed on the altar, and put them beside the altar.
verses.comment: Detailed listing of priestly garments follows Hebrew exactly.

verses.text: Then he shall take off his garments and put on other clothes, and carry the ashes outside the camp to a clean place.
verses.comment: ‘Clean place’ maintains Levitical purity theme.

verses.text: The fire on the altar must be kept burning; it must not go out. Every morning the priest shall add wood to it, lay out the burnt offering on it, and burn the fat of the fellowship offerings on it.
verses.comment: ‘Fellowship offerings’ for clarity; literal ‘peace offerings’.

verses.text: Fire shall be kept burning on the altar continually; it must not go out.
verses.comment: Repetition in Hebrew is for emphasis and is maintained.

verses.text: This is the law of the grain offering: The sons of Aaron shall present it before the Lord in front of the altar.
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew ‘torah’ usage for ‘instruction’ regarding offerings.

verses.text: He shall take a handful of the fine flour of the grain offering, with its oil and all the frankincense that is on the grain offering, and burn it on the altar as a pleasing aroma, as a memorial portion for the Lord.
verses.comment: 'Pleasing aroma' keeps literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Aaron and his sons shall eat the rest of it. It shall be eaten as unleavened bread in a holy place; they shall eat it in the courtyard of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: ‘Tent of Meeting’ is a literal translation.

verses.text: It must not be baked with leaven. I have given it as their portion from my food offerings; it is most holy, like the sin offering and the guilt offering.
verses.comment: ‘Most holy’ is a key Levitical category.

verses.text: Every male among Aaron's descendants may eat it. It is a perpetual statute throughout your generations, from the Lord's food offerings. Anything that touches them shall become holy.
verses.comment: ‘Perpetual statute’ is Hebraic legal language.

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: New section marker, duplicated per original Hebrew as Leviticus does.

verses.text: This is the offering that Aaron and his sons shall bring to the Lord on the day he is anointed: a tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a regular grain offering, half of it in the morning and half in the evening.
verses.comment: ‘Tenth of an ephah’ is kept as literal measure; clarifies time of offering.

verses.text: It shall be made with oil on a griddle; you shall bring it well mixed and present it in baked pieces as a grain offering, a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.comment: ‘Well mixed’ from Heb. ‘belulah’. ‘A pleasing aroma’ is a technical sacrificial phrase.

verses.text: The priest among Aaron’s sons who is anointed to succeed him shall offer it. It is a perpetual statute; the whole offering shall be burned to the Lord.
verses.comment: ‘Anointed to succeed him’ is a more literal rendering.

verses.text: Every grain offering of a priest shall be wholly burned; it shall not be eaten.
verses.comment: Emphasis: priestly grain offerings are not eaten, matching Hebrew syntax.

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Section heading, initiating instructions about sin offerings.

verses.text: Speak to Aaron and his sons, saying, This is the law of the sin offering: In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered, the sin offering shall be slaughtered before the Lord; it is most holy.
verses.comment: Standard Levitical instructions, all kept literal.

verses.text: The priest who offers it as a sin offering shall eat it; it shall be eaten in a holy place, in the courtyard of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.comment: ‘Eaten in a holy place’ is literal and follows priestly law.

verses.text: Whatever touches its flesh shall become holy. And if any of its blood is spattered on a garment, you shall wash that on which it was spattered in a holy place.
verses.comment: Maintains Levitical purity language.

verses.text: The earthenware vessel in which it is boiled shall be broken. But if it is boiled in a bronze vessel, that vessel shall be scoured and rinsed with water.
verses.comment: Adheres to ritual purity practices regarding utensils.

verses.text: Every male among the priests may eat of it; it is most holy.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘most holy’ retained verbatim.

verses.text: But any sin offering, some of whose blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting to make atonement in the Holy Place, shall not be eaten; it must be burned with fire.
verses.comment: ‘Shall not be eaten; it must be burned with fire’ follows Levitical prescription exactly.
